content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was going to write up an elegant summary of the game but honestly it doesn't need it. The game is easily the best golf sim I've played. The fact it has an unblievable course creator just puts it over the top. It's intuitive, fun and beautiful. You can play your course as your build it to ensure its exactly what you wanted. From placing objects such as buildings, trees, signs to sculpting a simple sand trap, you'll be in love with the ease at which it's all done.Ontop of that the game is gorgeous to look at, runs great and simply the best representation of golf you can find on PC. With an interesting multiplayer aspect you can challenge your friends or take on their ghost ball of their best score. So if you like golf, or golf creation and horribly written reviews, you should get this game.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								From what I have played so far, this might be one of the best golf games ever made and it is nice to finally see a game like this on Steam.The golf course creation tool is amazing.  You are able to create and customize your own golf course - It can be fully randomly generated or you can hand craft all of the holes, bunkers, trees, hills, anything you could think of, and you can share it to the public.As it is currently Early Access some game modes are not available as of yet, such as Tour's and Tournaments (These have a coming soon sign).  Stat tracking is also on the way.As far as I can see, there is no online multiplayer, however you do get to play against other players ghosts and The Golf Club supports local Multiplayer.Graphics wise - Very good, very nice looking game.Audio is also nice and the commentary that is in the game is a little different from games such as EA's  Tiger Woods games, and that is a nice change.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Usually when I look at a game, if it has mixed or below reviews I steer clear.  Luckily I got The Golf Club before it got too negative, because I personally have never had any issues with the performance of the game.  I don't doubt those who say they have, but I have had nothing but fun playing this game.On the hardware side, my PC has an i5, and a GTX760, and the game runs very smoothly, with the exception of the rare course with massive amounts of trees.  As far as content, well, you play golf.  Some people appear unhappy that there is no career mode, and while that would be cool, it wasn't part of the game I bought, and my family enjoys just sitting down for a round of golf when we get together.  I guess a lot of people are looking for a replacement for their previous favorite golf sims, and they find The Golf Club lacking, but if all you want is to play a round of golf when you feel like a round of golf, then this fits the bill nicely.

												I have never played a game as much as I have with The Golf Club. The Greg Norman Course designer is incredibly powerful, easy to use, and will have you creating fantastic courses in no time. The actual golf is great, relying on skill and not special pants you can buy that help you hit it 20 yards further. The career mode in the game is the only downside of the game, but if you head on over to TGCTours.com, you can play a REAL career mode with real players (check it out)!The community on the HB Forums and TGCTours.com is incredibly active, helpful and fun, which further makes this game a complete joy to play. content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												I've been waiting for a decent PC golf game since TW08.  This is almost that game.  Pros: Beautiful scenery, fairly natural swing control, solid in-game physics, wide variety of available courses, and a course editor that is a lot of fun.  Cons: Charging extra for a Season (Career) Mode is lame at best, any joy created by Season Mode is removed by fact that the software engineers chose to cheat the game horribly so their software would not "lose" - no regional Pro-Am EVER had a an entire top 10 at -11 in a single 18 hole round! Makes it tough to care about playing through it.  Overall, I would give the game as it stands right now, 3/6/16, a B-.  I will continue to play the game in other modes, but I am done with Seasons until the programmers stop cheating.  Save yourself $9.99 and skip skip it.added 3/7/16: Apparently the last update weighted all AI scores in all single player competitive events to the realm of absolutely stupid.  The last 18 hole event I managed to finish had the ENTIRE TOP 30 IN THE LOW 50s!  Until it is fixed, the only single player mode worth playing is single course, NO AI.

number of helpful: 92 of 133 people (69%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
												Update to the Updates: As of May 2015 they have made it so that in order to access some of features you have to buy a "DLC" which gives you access to the season pass features. So those of us that thought we spend $20 on a golf game just found out that we have to spend more money to get the other half of the game. On top of which the game still has a lot of development left despite the current release status. I felt this information was foremost to what I had to say about the game play that I experienced.Don't get me wrong. With the demise of the Tiger Woods Golf franchise us fairway junkies have been waiting for a game to come along and give us our knee pant, 9 iron fix. This game will be that, one day. Right now the game is being updated side by side with the console build of the game. Very little effort has been put into the controls for mouse users. So you either need to play with a Xbox controller for the PC or struggle to figure out the who what where when and why of how the game registers your mouse movement. There seems to be no ability to control roughly how hard you whack the ball, I still haven't seen much influence from using the fade and draw features. It makes it hard to not want to break your digital club around the electronic trees surounding you on the course. That all being said the game is still in early stages, one day the game might be the next great golf game for both PC and console. One day. Right now they are putting too much into social features like friends lists and competative play, meanwhile very little into the ability to teach players how to use their control systems to get precise shots. I'm no stranger to golf games but I'm having a very hard time being consistant with this game.Edit/Update: I've had the chance to play a few rounds with an XBox controller, and I've found the controls equally as hard to master. I think the problem still lies in not having a meter system either in game or at least as part of a learning feature that help you adjust to the control scheme.As for the rest of the game. A lot has been put into implementing the social features. The game has single, tournament and tour features. I really like the choice of play variety. However unless you happen to bring 3 other golfers in your bag at the bottom with the loose tees good luck. There is no match making feature that I've come across. So if you don't have other players to play with you wind up being matched with imaginary ghost players who represent some of the best players that have played that course. Talk about frustration. As I have said the controls will drive you batty, but it's worse when an imaginary player with a -7 is driving them right to the green, taunting you while you try to work your way out of the sand. The feature was so annoying the do now have a way to turn it off. So obviously this game does want to promote social play. But for those of us who don't have golf loving gaming buddies it would be nice to have a match feature to meet up with other single players for some rounds. I have not used the course making feature, but I've read that it too can be very difficult to use. However there are many well made player designed courses, that is a great feature of the game.While they are constantly improving the social features of the game, the frustration of the controls combined with the under developed ability to actually use the full social interface make all the implemented features still seem far off. I will revisit this game soon hopefuly after some more updates to see what they have done.February 2015 update: I finally uninstalled the game. The last updates have seemed to revert the controls back to being wonky and unpredictable. Which is a shame because right before that I was finally have to have a full round with a negative score. The controls seemed to be getting better. That has seemed to change. I'll check back maybe in the spring or summer to see if after a few more updates if the game has made any improvements.

number of helpful: 32 of 39 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												First off, while this is marked as a recommended title, there are issues to be aware of.This game is fun, but it's missing some key elements that sports type games need to be an overall good experience. There is nothing in the way of a practice mode, or even a basic tutorial. You're thrust into the game, and left to figure out how to play on your own. I don't understand why there was such an oversight in this design, and the developers even acknowledge the lack of a practice/tutorial mode in a video on their own page. That being said, it is great fun. The courses, while not real world copies, are challenging, and quite rewarding to those that take risks in their shots. The game mechanics are good, and the game is engrossing enough to have you looking for you club, when you've missed a shot by inches, and decide to throw it. The bad is this. I felt like I've played this game before, at least, I've played PGA Golf Games before, but they felt like there was more to it. This feels less than, because it's more simulator, and less casual. Putting is challenging, and there aren't 15 different types of overlays setup for you to use. Instead you get a grid, and a camera you can move. It feels basic, but it's more challenging in the end. If that is what the devs were going for, which I believe they were, then they hit the mark. This is not a Tiger Woods game, this is a Golf Simulator, rage included at no extra charge. p.s. please add some sort of practice or tutorial modes. That's really a rookie mistake.

number of helpful: 31 of 39 people (79%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												I don't get too wound up about my golf game, and it's a good thing I don't. Otherwise, long ago I would have thrown myself in the nearest water hazard along with my clubs. Enjoying a nice day on a gorgeous course is enough. The Golf Club captures this essence in both the challenge of perfecting your swing and the pride of being able to create your own gorgeous courses. But, is that beauty enough?The game's course creation tools are impressive in their ability to not only let you build detailed courses, but the scalability of the tools themselves. You can apply some macro-levels rules to shape your course with simple min/max sliders – like if you want your course as a whole to be hilly or have lots of water – or dive into placing individual trees, objects, and even whales. The menu presentation is straightforward, but there are times like placing water, for instance, where the macro and micro tools can cause confusion on how to exactly get what you want. Regardless, the game puts a lot of power in your hands, and with a little tinkering you soon learn how to efficiently work with the tools and start making some sweet courses.I was really impressed with the naturally adaptability of your holes in the broader context of the world's environment. Moving a hole en masse, rearranging holes' order, adding/subtracting holes, and even switching out the overall theme of the environment (you can choose from desert, autumn/forest, rural, alpine, and the wild Scotland-like links terrain) is well done.You can also dive in and playtest your hole at any time; dropping your ball in a specific location or playing the whole thing. Finding and playing other people's creations is easy as well, and you can use them to put together your own tour of courses.The golf gameplay itself is challenging and satisfying. The right analog swing requires precision, especially when applying draw or fade, and a minimal pre-swing HUD is hard at first. Gauging your swing power while putting, in particular, takes getting used to, but it won't take long to develop a rhythm and feel to your swing.As well-crafted as the game is, it's missing a sense of progression that drives you forward. While creating the course of your dreams (or someone else's nightmares) feels good, I missed a larger structure. Visual or physical golfer upgrades, an overarching rewards system tied to your stats, or even a career shell are missing and there's lost momentum within the game because of it. Seeing what kinds of courses I and others could come up with and the challenges therein is motivating, but the sustenance it provides is impermanent.The Golf Club delivers as a course creator, and it's no slouch swinging the clubs, either. What's missing is the personality: the larger career structure and personal investment in your avatar to spur players on and elevate the experience from a nice set of features to the complete package   9/10Appsy doodles

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I think if you want a Golf simulator, and have the patience to learn the mechanics of this game and how they work, you will love it.   Folks that are looking for an arcade golf game, probably won't like it, and will quit before they give it a chance.Personally I really like the game.  Once you get used to the controls, it "feels" like you really are playing golf.  You have to concentrate on each shot, and not every shot is perfect, some are really bad, sometimes you hit it perfect...but thats how it is when you really play.   The point is, the feeling you get with the controller, is about like the feeling you would have really swinging the club, from the mental point of view.I'm not sure of the specs of the reviews I see that say the game is not optimized or runs slow.  It runs perfectly fine on my machine  and the graphics look beautiful.  Multiplayer works great also, a friend and I play together and take turns and it is quite fun.The only cons I have is that there is no tutorial or practice area that I could find.  It would be nice if they at least had a tutorial in game describing the controls, and a driving range that you could click on and practice swings.   I think I eventually found this info on their website, but it was hard to find.   Also, a bit of advice, if you are using a controller, make sure you have an Xbox based one, not the older D based (Sony) kind.Final verdict in a nutshell - GREAT game, very much worth it, IF you put the time in to learn it properly.

number of helpful: 19 of 23 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												This game is turning into a solid golf game, the graphics are great to look at and the gameplay is getting there IMO. The main selling point of this game for me is the GNCD, the course designer. I have spent many hours on this and once you get the hang of it, your only limited by your imagination.This is a worthy successor to the EA TW series and plays a lot like it too, well if you consider that most of the people that worked on that game are the ones that developed TGC. The good thing about this game is the fact that the developers are still working on it and fixing bugs and adding stuff to it all the time, once it’s finished then this will be a solid and enjoyable title for everyone to play. The only real problem with this game for me is the graphics issue if you own an AMD Radeon card, especially the newer models, but I think this is more to do with the Unity engine than anything else, as playing this game with an Nvidia card seems less problematic and appears to run better. Although this game has been developed for the PC it still very much feels like a port, as its main focus IMO is for the console market, after all that’s where the money is.Anyway, if you’re in any doubt about buying this game, then I would recommend you do, especially if you like golf and have been looking for a worthy successor to EA TW series. There are also more updates coming soon, and with the number of courses made by the community, then its longevity is assured. It’s not quite the golf sim this has been hailed to be, as that title I think belongs to another game currently in development.Anyway this is money well spent on.Update: I can't believe that this game has now been out for over 20 months, it has had a lot of fixes applied to it and it certainly has improved since its early access days. Graphics wise this game is great to look at and I can’t fault it on that front, however the gameplay is a lot easier than it used to be IMO, it’s easier to hit straighter shots and plays more like an arcade game rather than an actual golf sim, even with all the aid’s turned off. This game still suffers with issues, originally with AMD cards and then with Nvidia cards, although fixes have been applied to fix the Nvidia issues, I wish the same could be said for AMD users, anyway putting those glitches aside, this is still a great game and I would still rate this up there with the likes of EA TW series. The games real selling point for me has been and will always be the Greg Normal Course Designer and the thousands of community designed courses out there, some of course (no pun intended) better than others. And the great thing about it is that they are all free to play, let’s hope that this stays that way. Player customisation has been cranked up and the variety of shirts and trousers available to dress your player up has increased, but I would like to see more with also some community made ones thrown in too. The selection of golf clubs has not changed and I believe that this is something that could certainly be improved along with the option to hit shots with more back spin etc.If your looking for a game to play against AI, then you'll be dissapointed, although you can play against the "ghost" of other players who have played the courses, whoch is better than nothing I guess. This game does not have crowds, as it was only ever inteneded to be a week-end golfer type of game and not a full blown EA-TW clone as it does not have the PGA logo or backing.This game has only had one DLC to date, which the community was in arms about, but IMO you don't have to buy it, it wasn't like the game was unplayable without it.@King Kyne, for a while I did feel this was a good Sim game, but then I started to play PG and somehow the gameplay in that was a lot harder and felt more realistic IMO. TGC feels a lot more arcade-ish, and since the updates, hitting the ball straight has become a lot easier. The game feels like its holding your hand and not letting you make mistakes too much, it almost feels like its restricting you. I don't associate a SIM game with something difficult, far from it, a SIM should allow you to do your own thing, it then becomes as individual as you. I have played PG for a while now, and since they introduced the horizontal swing mechanics, I personally feel that the game has improved in my estimation, not because it’s become harder, but I can now shape the flight of the ball better, if only it was that easy in real life! The reason the mechanics in PG works for me is that there is an option to create a draw or a fade, make the ball go higher or lower, but it still depends on how you “swing” the club, so it’s down to the player’s skill rather than the settings that you dial up. Please don’t get me wrong TGC is a great game, but it feels like something that you could pick up straight away, while PG is something else and needs practice if you want to get better at it.I guess that’s my definition of a SIM, it needs to feel natural and with enough practice you start to reap the benefits for all that hard work you’ve put in.I play with all the aids turned off in both games, and PG still feels more realistic IMO sorry to say.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												When I bought this game, their FAQ said they were still considering incorporating a 3-click shot meter, which I assumed would be optional.  I understood they wanted a 'realistic' mechanism to focus on the 'feel' of golf, but I hoped, because of their FAQ, that they would add the 3-click shot meter for those people who preferred a lighter fun vs super serious.  Eventually they dug their feet in the ground and decided they wanted 'realism,' which completely killed my desire to play the game.  While it seems their mechanism for a console game controller works okay, their mouse and keyboard mechanism is too frustrating and imprecise to be fun.  At least for me (some may disagree).Consequentially, I felt like I had wasted my money, which inspired this less than positive review.  Alternatively, if Steam allowed (easier) refunds, I would have done so, and would not have been as frustrated, and would have just waited for a golf game that is more accommodating to us 'less-serious' golfers.

number of helpful: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												Great golf sim with a few quirks.I love this game - play it several times a week with my Dad. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who wants a good solid golf game, but it's certainly not perfect. Probably easiest to sum up with a list of pros and cons:ProsThe core of the game is rock solid and realistic. The feel of the swing, the look of the courses, the physics, and the action of the ball are all great. Fantastic course editor - best I've ever seen in a golf game. You can play courses created by other palyers or generate a fresh new course with just a few clicks. You'll certainly never run out of courses to play. Very satisfying when you put in a good round because you know you earned it. :)Skill is not stat based. If your get better at the game it's because you've learned to play better.Devs are still improving the game. I've been playing since the first day of Early Access and the Devs have been communicating and responding - while still sticking to their gameplan. They haven't fixed all the quirks, but the game has seen steady improvements over the months.ConsSome machines might struggle with the graphics. Seems to recquire more CPU/GPU power than you might think. Only a few graphics settings to adjust.The swing controls can be hard to learn. I love the controls (I use xbox 360 controller) but some people seem to get frustrated. No option for the old 'three-click' method that is popular in other games. I think this is part of the 'level playing field' that the devs are shooting for. They have worked hard to make the competition skill-based and fair.The interface is sometimes clunky. All the info and controls are there, but sometimes they are not intuitive.  Took me a long time to figure out what the two different distances on the putting green were (one is distance to the cup, and the other is the distance to your aiming marker). I still can't figure out how to properly show an instant replay. :)No career mode or similar extra features. The Tiger Woods games were full of all sorts of extras and some people might expect them here. Presentation is somewhat sparse. The voicover/commenter is well done, but there is very little 'juice' or graphical embellishments to spice things up.For me the pros definitely outweigh the cons. This is one of my most played games of 2014 and I expect it will be in 2015, too.

Posted: October 6, 2014
												The graphics are nice, but this just isn't a good golf game compared to other available PC golf games (such as Customplay 2010 or Hank Haney's World Golf- which both use the same basic golf engine and both having comparable realism to The Golf Club).  Too much is missing in terms of gameplay and game types (there are no skins or stableford games), and overall this feels like a rushed console port.  The mouse swing never feels right, and is extremely unforgiving.   While the random course generator is a nice feature, the editor itself is tedious to use and not as powerful as the editors featured in other golf games (such as the Links or Jack Nicklaus series).  Do yourself a favor and avoid purchasing this game.

number of helpful: 21 of 29 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I have purchased only a few titles through Steam's Early Access.  There is a trust factor that you hope the developer upholds.  Assetto Corsa, Planetary Annihilation, and now The Golf Club (TGC) have formed an elite level of Early Access titles.  These games exemplify building a customer-developer relationship founded on trust.  The quality that is already built into TGC has me feeling satisfied, and VERY excited for the future of the product.  I am amazed at the depth of challenge.  Right when I thought that I "got it", I played Coronaca against some ghosts, and the greens positively whipped me (not to mention the devilishly placed fairway bunkers!!).  This game has so much potential. I can't wait for tournaments!  Building in a course designer from the start was pure genius.  You have instilled a sense of value for me.  What I really want to compliment are the design decisions.  You are making really smart moves.  The ghost method of multiplayer suits me very well.  I don't have to wait for others, worry about lag/disconnects, or even if I personally run out of free time.  The swing method is awesome.  I love that it is based on the character model swinging, not some power meter.  It really makes the game a challenge and requires that I keep my head in it.  Once I start to get lazy, there goes a slice into the woods!  There are subtleties that I love too, such as you never cut off the guy doing the voice over.  Even if I quickly move through the scorecard to the next hole, he finishes what he is saying.  I like that.  It feels polished.Thank you HB for getting me excited about a PC golf game again, and living up to expectations.  Job well done!  I'll happily continue to be a part of The Golf Club.

												This is a great golf game. There are many golf games out there, however they lack in the PC world. The overall feel of this game -- as far as the gameplay and layout of the game goes -- is really quite astonishing. Unlike a lot of games, with this game you have to take everything into account from the wind, speed of the fairways/greens, slope of the holes, etc. It really is a very neurotic game and you have to be smart how you play it. On a difficulty perspective, this game is very challenging. It takes lots of practice on each course to master it. It's almost like actually golfing where you have to take notes, make adjustments, and eat it when you fail. I highly recommend getting this game if you're an avid golf fan like I am.

												I've had my eye on this game for quite some time. I picked it up during a sale recently and do not regret it at all.I'm a former Links player and I've been looking for a simliar experience for quite some time. This game captures that experience. number of helpful: 13 of 16 people (81%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												There is a huge lack of golf sims out there - remember Microsoft Golf, Arnold Palmer Links, and of course Tiger Woods? Now there are basically The Golf Club and WGT. And between the two, I'll take The Golf Club any day.The graphics are good - I won't say GREAT - and the sounds/speech is good (although the commentator gets a bit annoying after a bit). Mechanics are solid, certainly better than the ridiculous 2 click meter used in WGT. If you like real swing method using your mouse, rather than clicking on a meter, TGC is for you. It doesn't quite rise to the level of the swing meter on Tiger Woods - which I consider to be the best golf game ever - but it's not too far off. All in all, you can play 18 (or 9) holes and have a darned enjoyable time; for true golf enthusiasts, this is probably as close to the real thing as you can get without lugging your clubs out to the local links.A few negatives: the match-making. NOT easy to jump into a multi-player game against real people. The menus are not very easy to navigate, despite their initial appearance with large labelled icons. You have to click and click and click to find a course to play, set up the paramaters and match type and difficulty, then when trying to find opponents to play TGC will automatically locate "players" and fill your roster to the number you have selected (2, 3, 4, etc). The only problem - no guarantee you will actually get REAL players. Once the round starts, most of the time you find yourself playing "Ghosts" of the actual players. I.e., they are not logged in, but TGC selected them based on their skill levels, rating on the course you are playing, etc - and popped their "ghosts" into the game with you. Huh??? So, 8 times out of 10, you will find yourself playing against basically 2 or 3 other computer AI players. Needless to say, not a very social occasion. Try chatting with them. The ONLY way you can play against other REAL live people is if you manually select someone you have "Friended" and who you KNOW is in the game. If they aren't in the game, and you locate them by UserName, you will just get their "ghost" again. You CANNOT just randomly play games against other live players. This is one of the biggest faults in this game to me.I do find the game fun, but there is .... something... missing. Hard to put a finger on it. Individually, all the components of a great golf game are there. But put together, it falls a bit short, and I wish I could describe specifically what that is. Difficulty-wise, it IS hard to get below par (and I've played a ton of golf games for a lot of years, and consider myself pretty darn good). Putting especially is a pain in the butt. There is NO power meter. On ANY swing. So you have no real idea how hard you are swinging.  There is NO swing meter, so you have NO idea how far your backswing is. There are NO bars period. You just totally wing it. Most of the time just pulling all the way back on the mouse for a full swing works, but what about that sand wedge just off the green? It says it is 40 ft from the pin, and your wedge has a maximum distance of 50 ft, so you don't want to do a full swing - but how do you judge what the right backswing is? 80%, you think? OK - so how do you swing the club back around 80%? No meter=no way of knowing how far back you are swinging your club. Again - you just wing it, and 9 times out of 10 you will wind up doing a full swing even though you didn't want to. Or you overcompensate, and wind up doing a little 20% chip that sends the ball 2 feet. VERY annoying. I read all of the other reviews saying they LOVE this aspect, but they are "purists" who think that any kind of power or swing meter is "cheating." Whatever. If I want that level of realism, I'll go play real golf at the local course. For a game - I want at least some idea of how hard I am "swinging" my "club."All in all, I give this a thumbs-up, but to be honest I have stopped playing it very much due to the swing mechanics described above. If they ever add a power/backswing meter, and if they make it so you can actually play REAL LIVE people randomly -  I will be reinvigorated to play, guarantee it. In the meantime, if you love golf and virtual golf games, you will definitely enjoy this game, even though it may not rise to the top of your "Favorite golf game" list.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												tl;dr: if you're a casual golf game fan, The Golf Club is awesome. I can't speak for whether or not it will satisfy hardcore fans, because I'm not one.So, I've been looking for a good PC golf game for a while. I'm not a golfer in real life, nor am I a particularly hardcore fan of the genre. I just played Tiger Woods '06/'07 on X-Box 360 a while ago, thought they were fun, and have been looking for something similar. I stayed away from The Golf Club while it was in Early Access because, well, I don't do Early Access. And I kinda forgot about it for a while.A few days ago, Jack Nicklaus' Perfect Golf came out, and I thought "Hey, maybe this will be my cup of tea!"I honestly can't even tell you if it's my cup of tea or not, because Perfect Golf's UI/UX is absolutely atrocious. After 20 frustrating minutes of fighting against the game just to try and learn the basics, I uninstalled it and got a refund. Maybe there is a good golf game in there, I don't know, but I should not have to untangle a convoluted mess just to understand the basics of the game.Then I saw the Golf Club was out of Early Access, and I grabbed it. Within THREE MINUTES, I had a handle on the game.Now again, I'm not a hardcore golf guy, so maybe there's a bunch of depth to this game that I'm missing. There probably is. I can't tell you the difference between a chip and a pitch, and I can't remember which side is draw and which side is fade, and I've never adjusted the point of impact on the ball. All of that stuff exists in The Golf Club, so I assume I still have a long way to go to mastering it. But unlike Perfect Golf, the basics here are simple and intuitive. Everything about the controls, the menus, the UI/UX experience, makes sense. If you put a controller in my hand and tell me to play a game I've never played before, and I've got the basics down in three minutes? You have done something very, very right.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												The Golf Club is by far the best game I've ever played.    The gameplay,   and the course creator will keep this game growing for years to come.   There are some incredible course designers that put courses out on a daily basis so the replay value here is crazy good.    The devs are quick to fix things and add new features but they're a small team so you have to be patient.     The game has grown leaps and bounds within the last year and it's light years better than some of the current competiton in my opinion.A few cons is that they really need to work on the social aspect of the game so that it's easier to find multiplayer games.  They are lacking typical gamemodes that you expect to see and they don't and will never have a conventional lobby.   They basically just have you send an invite to a friend to join you a the course but only half the time it works.  You are constantly having to kick your friend from the game and re add him to just see him play.    Like I said,  it's still the best game I've played but the multi player taking a backseat to some of the other features has always left me scratching my head..The course creator is revolutionairy,  it's just flat out amazing.   This game appeals more to the guy that wants a relaxing real round of golf without all the EA sports glitz and glamour.   This game can be played with a controller,  PS4 is what I use..  I own the game on my ps4 and PC,  and I get all the updates on my PC as soon as they're ready which is awesome.  Honestly though,  the game plays just as well on the ps4.  It seems to me that they've taken lots of time to optizimze it for the consoles and I can certainly undertand why considering that is the majority of their audience.I give this game maximum stars, even with it's issues...   Also,  if you play the a course insipred by the "Delta Theme"   I was the guy that named that theme!!!  I won a "name that theme"  competition and the boys from HBS sent me some cool swagg for my winning submission.One of the big fish up at the golf club name is Anthony Kyne,  and he is a very likable chap,  who does live streams often where he takes questions from us mere mortals...  I have grown fond of Anthony over the last year and have his face tattooted on my buttocks ;)

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												The game garners much hate for not having the old links 386 styled 3 click swing. They opt instead to go for a meterless true motion swing that ends up being played best from a gamepad then a keyboard and mouse, if this bothers you then perhaps its not quite the golf game your looking for.I still play and enjoy the port of Golden Tee golf on the PC and for years there was no real suitable replacement and while there is no "replacement" for GTgolf, I do find this game just as enjoyable but for some very different reasons. The Golf Club comes into its own for the way it deals with sloping surfaces and also implements probrably the greatest putting grid known to man. It also happens to have some great 2015 graphics and where it lacks in flair it more then makes up for it with a very solid golf simulation.While it drops the ball in adding some excitement via sound effects and lacks more engaging commentary, it says nothing about the simulation beneath it, which is crisp. The game itself does require some beefy hardware to get medium + settings at 1080p. I can recommend this game to any Golf fan but keep in mind to get the best swings control and results you should get your settings to allow 60 frames per second when playing.Played onAvg FPS: 50-70Settings: Medium preset from launcher config with res @ 1920x1080i5 2500k @ 4.0GHzR9 270X 2GB16GB 1600MHz DDR3Pros+ Great looking (even on medium)+ Awesome course designer and courses+ Less ability for people to "calculate" their swing (aka cheating with math)Cons- Sound design is stale (some golf claps and some flair would be nice)- Difficult to play for mouse/kb- Perhaps boring to more casual golf fans that like arcade golf more- System requirements are quite highBottom LineIf your into golf games then its a no brainer buy, if you like Hot Shots perhaps you should think twice about getting into the simulation.Overall80/100

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Not a fan. While I realize this game is advertised as a sim, I wasn't under the understanding that sim implied 0 degree of consistency over the controls. This game seems to be optimized to use a controller as opposed to the standard keyboard mouse input of a typical golf game (non-sim) which is fine, but I think this game could do well to have some gauge that could be toggled on or off to show you at least somewhere in the ballpark of how hard you're hitting."We’ve created and fine tuned a swing mechanic that is more about feeling and fluidity above the users’ accuracy of hitting a marker on a power bar. Whilst anyone will be able to pick the controller up and play comfortably, the best players on the global leaderboards will be those with the best feel for the different golf shots and who are able to take into account ball lie, weather and terrain conditions."I find the above to be utter garbage. The mechanic relies in NO way on feeling or fluidity, but instead an attempt to make visual placeholders of where a club is to indicate how powerful you're going to hit the ball. I also highly doubt most people will be abl to "pick the controller up and play comfortably." I only wish I hadn't believed their sales pitch, because it's anything but accurate. I can only hope it changes in the future, but I kind of doubt it, as the mechanic is already in place.I find the only way to fine tune your shot is to adjust the loft, which seems silly when normally one would simply hit the ball with less oomph. In short, the controls for this game, while refreshing and new, are in massive need of improvement/options. Had I known ahead of time what the controls were like, I very simply would've kept my $35. The big caveat to Steam is that there are no refunds, and now I'm out money for a game I likely will not play in the future. That said, the game itself is beautiful, and the audio is crisp, if not a bit repetetive (the actual sounds you hear on the course ie.) your ball hitting the ground, seem to be one and the same.) making it a very aesthetically appealing experience. Unfortunately I'm a firm believer that gameplay > aesthetics.

number of helpful: 30 of 49 people (61%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												The Golf Club is a great idea. Place a golf sim game on the PC platform when other developers refuse to and give it a course creator. What could possibly go wrong with such a strong idea? Many things.First and foremost this game does not run well. Even on powerful machines you will innevitably find yourself playing on Medium or lower settings just to get a decent and constant framerate. This is something that can be overlooked by many but still needs to be stated as it is important.Ball striking is solid and good until you get close to the green. Due to the minimal control you have over shot distance anything other than a full 100% shot into the green is unlikely to land anywhere near where you intend it to. Putting is also a widely varying affair where getting correct distances is nearly impossible.The course creator is one of the shining positives in The Golf Club. It has enough functionality and customization to allow for a large variety of course types and difficulties. However, more recent updates had altered some of the terrain functionality making it difficult to create smoothed surfaces with large scale changes. Still, the course creator is definitely a strong point.The largest issue with this game currently is the seeming abandonment of the PC Platform. With their release on PS4 and XBox One, HB Studios have given continuous updates to both of the console platforms, yet have not updated the PC release with any of that content for 2 months as of this writing. ('Release was on October 8th, currently December 15th) This is the most diseheartening thing HB could have done. The console versions now have more HB created cources, 2 more course creator themes, and more bug fixes than the PC version.With this last point in mind, I cannot recommend this game. It is a wonderful idea with a nice course creator that seems to have been abandoned before it could be made into something great. If you really want a golf game on the PC platform and have no other options then pick this up when it is on sale for 50% off or more, otherwise just steer clear. If they ever come back and give the PC platform some love, it may be worth the asking price, but as it stands it is not.Edit: As of 12/19/2014 the PC and console versions are finally on the same patch. Going forward it is difficult to tell if they will become split so disparately as before but this does not change the core idea that it is better to wait for a sale for this game than to buy it at full price.

												So far I am really enoying this simulation.  The sounds and graphics are very good and the frame rate is smooth (as long as you don't max out tree detail draw distance).I initially tried playing witht he mouse and found it to be quite frustrating. I switched to the Gamepad and that has made a huge difference.  Judging putting power can be a chore at first, but with practice you will get accustomed to it.The great thing about this game is there is no skill progression. Nothing to add points to  in order to increase accuracy, distance, etc.  It is all about how well you can use the sticks, judge the fairways and greens, and select good shots that setup good follow up shots.Also, no after striking modifications. Everything you do is done prior to ball striking, once it is in the air you are an observer.  I have worked my handicap index to just over 8, and won my local club season. Currently  in 14th place in the amateur season.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												((I wanted to add this info to top afterwards, since I failed to mention this before:Unless one specifically goes offline or play the offline-single-player-mode "Seasons", all the shots are recorded to online-storages, which is really amazing to me considering I've gotten to a point I semi-refuse to play "hitscan-client-side-detection-only"-games and such without replay-systems nowadays.Unfortunately currently the replay-system is very barebones with only the playback option available, this far-cry to systems like "Mario Golf Advance + Toadstool"-tour had.But hopefully this system will get further improved in the sequel / 2.0-update (AKA. "The Golf Club 2").)) The Overview:Alright, since the game currently is more closer to "complete"-golf-game nowadays, I suppose it's finally a time to give an overview on this title.First of, what "The Golf Club" is:- "Bare-bones "just golf""-game with emphasis on simulation.What "The Golf Club" is not:- "Arcade-like"-golf game with "Career"-modes to become stronger, more "bling", or anything else similar: It's "Just-golf".I personally have nicknamed this game as "Tiger Woods PGA Tour Online "without gorilla-suit" and with perma-TrueSwing-mode"; not much else to comment about that aside that both games are / were quite well built into Unity3D-engine.((Those who are interested though, the "Tiger Woods PGA Tour 12 - Masters" is quite similar both the UI and the golf-play-wise, minus of course the (identical) "Greens Fee" and other things that were in "PGA Tour Online."))In other words for the most part your avatar customization is mainly limited to "etique"-abiding outfits.And your golf-equipments are standardized performance-wise, meaning that there are no "power-golf-clubs". There might be more "style-suiting" equipment-options available in future (E.G slightly more wider+lighter-clubs to allow pitching from tougher spots with less "carry" due lessened-weight), but that's just one personal wishful-thinking.((Fair to mention that I personally mainly play with the least amount of "assistance-UI" as possible (green-grid, shot-direction-reticle, wind-indicator, and such), to which I base my overview on))As hinted earlier, the players are also limited to "semi-TrueSwing" system, since it's by design that there is no "traditional 3-click-system" in-game to emphasis on more "feeling"-gameplay instead of being cold-hard-mechanical.Unfortunately at the moment, there is no "dry-hitting" so playing by just "the feel" alone isn't necessarily working for the favor of the players.And since the "hitting-indicator" isn't currently working exactly in real-time either (it appears only after the hit is done), the game turns unfortunately into quite fiddly "percentage"-game because players are semi-forced to number-crunch with the "lofts" of their clubs if they want to make more accurate shots. So in the end the hitting-game (currently) is mainly limited to adjusting the loft of the clubs and hitting with max-power, since for the most part the "fine-tune-club-action" seen in various other "TrueSwing"-game is quite non-existent.Point being, the swing+putting-system could be better since it's currently heavily dependant on "power" only (indicated by how "back" you "Pull" the clubs). But it suffices, somewhat.As for the courses (of the amount which in theory are infinite), I personally can only give a / some warning(s): Given that the major-amount of the courses are done by "everyday-non-pro"-players, there are going to large amount of courses not following the "official" (real-life) recommendations; This is very important thing to remember, especially if you're into regular tournament participations.- Especially before the "Out-of-Bounds" (or "O.B")-system was implemented in, there is large amount of "Trap-courses", meaning that if you are very unfortunate to hit your ball into one of the "trap-valleys", you're going to be guaranteed end-up getting that "+9" (or any other "max-hit"-amount set).- Since the game doesn't yet support the "cup-place-randomization", you're going to end seeing a huge amount of these placed in the middle of "spiral-macaroni"-greens.What I am trying to say is the a quite a little amount of course-designers follow the following recommendation: "A player putting from above the hole should be able to stop the ball near the hole." Okay, that is just one part of the whole thing....For those who are interested for more info, here are few links:http://www.barryrhodes.com/2011/11/position-of-hole-on-putting-green.htmlhttp://www.randa.org/en/Rules-and-Amateur-Status/Guidance-on-Running-a-Competition.aspx?chapter=4&section=2In overall, "The Golf Club" is a nice change in the golf-game scenery in which you can simply jump-in and jump-out freely without need of worrying whether your have enough good "gear" or otherwise "stats" to simply play both by yourself and competing with other players.The issues mentioned above aside, the gameplay itself is pretty solid.And this game  isn't all that power-demanding alongside the game itself is being quite stable (at least on my quite low-spec-computer).On a extra note, the game also features a quite extensive API for those people who'd like to make more organized leagues and similar organizations.This allows websites such as tgctours.com to have more accurate data on the players themselves.Who knows though what the developers will eventually bring to this game; the possibilities are almost unlimited!

number of helpful: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
												Being a avid golfer in real life playing of an +2 handicap myself I have played most of the golf games out there. And to be honest most of them become boring because they are way to easy to master. The golf club however always seems to have a new challenge up its sleeve. I have read many reviews slamming the inconsistency of playing with your mouse. My experience is that yes it is challenging but fair. I have played and struggled but learned with each round (Pro Tip, get yourself a proper mouse and a good gaming mouse pad I recommend a Gamdias Pad). Through practice and practice you can achieve amazing things and compete without a gamepad or building a swing rail(cheating in my opinion.). Now my in game handicap is at +9 and getting better(Just shot a 55 at Flathead).You would think that if you played off a +9 you have mastered the game, but you would be mistaken. In elite tournaments playing on your handicap will only just get you in the top 50. Its all about the quest we as golfers share but never attain...Perfection. The quest to be the best and the opportunity to really compete with thousands of other golfers is what makes the golfers club an amazing golf game. Now to the game play. Is it perfect? No, there are problems, especially regarding the rules. With rules I refer to the lack of dropping in the game when you are unfortunate enough to land in a water hazard of end up in an unplayable lie. Most times the re-hit option is enforced only on a rare occasion does the game will drop for you. As for the unplayeble situation, it play it as it lies(or restart ;-) ) There is no custom drop option which is annoying.(They have rectified the droping problem with the last update!04/05/2015)How do you become good? Swinging straight is only 10pecent of the battle. You really have to think about you shot: Club selection, Shot Type, Height, Shape and the most important part of all, where do you want to hit the next shot from. Especially when it comes to where you what to putt from. Speed and rythm of your swing is also very important. Don't think a fast back and through will do it or get you more distance.The Golf Club is an Awsome golf game and I feel it is one of my best purchases on steam to date. I can't wait for the Seasons DLC to come out. No problem with buying it as a add on. I feel I have gotten more that my moneys worth so far.Highly recommended!!!!! You get out what you put in just like in real life golf!

												A cool game with great basic courses  and game modes.  If you're looking for some decent courses, a good editor, and decent controls this is the golf game for you.That said. content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												After many years of shelling out money for other golf games and then having to pay more for extra golf courses, I've finally found the ideal solution to my common peeve.  A course with a built-in creator.  There are thousands of courses to choose from.The controls are similar  to the TW series from EA.  It's a game that you're going to struggle with at first, but as you keep playing and practicing, you will get much better.  There are no special power-ups, pants, or hats, just an equal playing field where the individuals that are the most skilled, shine.The creator is accessible to everyone.  You can have it design the course for you and automatically generate a course based on some random parameters you enter.  Or you can start with a blank slate, place the 1st tee and green wherever you want and draw the fairway in between and then plant the bunkers.The creator may seem daunting to some and they may find themselves intimidated by all the features and controls.  But there is an incredibly active community on the game website's forum http://www.hb-studios.com/forum/index.php#c7, and a well built community focused on competitive tournaments that are cross platform http://tgctours.com/Best parts about this game is that it's constantly upgrading and improving.  If you had a look at this game when it was first released, take another look at it.  There have been dozens of major features added to the creator AND play modes with more on the way.  Also, if you ever have  problem, the developers and players are quick to answer questions and help you when you run into trouble.This is a golf game you shouldn't ignore.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												First off, if you are looking for a Tiger Woods replacement, then this may not be for you. The graphics are excellent on my laptop (i7 2.4, Geforce GT740 and 16g Ram) - smooth scrolling and sharp, clear detail. I found a controller the easiest / best way to play the game.In my opinion, the game does not need a career mode as suggested by some players. Yes, it can be repetative, but so is the actual game of golf. There are currently in excess of 50,000 user created courses, some better than others. You can create your own course in five minutes if you like, or spend hours adjusting pretty much any aspect of each hole. Having access to user created courses, competitions and tours adds an extra dimension to The Golf Club that I have not come across in other golf games. I have no problem with the wind and find this fairly accurate, along with 'clubbing up or down' depending on the height of the greenThe introduction of the Handicap system means you can continually try to lower your handicap on the handicap rated courses or simply play as many different courses as you want.One thing I would like to see is a layout map of a course (like you get on the back of a scorecard) before I select to play it. Some more courses from the developers would also be good.........Overall, the best golf game by far - no gimicks, just as much golf as you want. I can see why some may not like this game because of it's simplicity - if that is the case, get yourself an old copy of Tiger Woods :-)

number of helpful: 43 of 77 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014



YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: The Golf Club 

			Views: 2,292		

			Trent hits the links in The Golf Club to see if EA's golf franchise finally has some worthy competition. Please like and subscribe for more reviews, gameplay, and discussions!		

It's been quite some time since golf fans have been spoiled for choice. EA has dominated one of the worlds most regal games for more than a decade and those who play games on a PC in particular have been left with little to no choice in how they hit the links. Enter The Golf Club, a new Golf simulator from HB studios that doesn't boast PGA licensing or tons of product placement, but it does offer a massive game changing feature that is sure to land in the fairway with most virtual golfers: a course editor. Instead of shelling out absurd sums of money for new courses players now have access to a surprisingly robust course creation tool with Greg Norman's name slapped across it. So does The Golf Club burst on the scene like Tiger Woods circa 1997 or does it choke like Sergio Garcia on Sunday at a major? Without PGA licensing, The Golf Club feels more like a virtual golf outing with friends than a tense and competitive sports simulation. There isn't a character creator, no RPG like leveling or character progression, no unlockables nor upgrades. The Golf Club also doesn't offer any alternative modes like challenges or mini games. You simply pick a course or a tournament and hit the links. Asynchronous play is generally the preferred play mode if you don't have good buddies available for eighteen since it allows brisk competitive play. Your competitors strokes are shown as you take your own and minimal load times keep the pace up and reduces the tedium present in other golf titles. A generic announcer provides the only semblance of professional golf tournament ambiance since galleries of spectators, scoreboards and tournament sponsor signs are all absent from the game's courses. The announcer does a decent job of reacting to your shots and making accurate assessments of the conditions on the course, but his personality is on par with a rusty, dinged-up pitching wedge. It's a shame that HB studios didn't utilize the freedom of not being a PGA licensed product to offer some more festive commentary a la Gary McCord at the 1994 Masters Tournament.  The Golf Club's bare bones feature set and lack of atmosphere and ambiance are not it's most prominent offense however, its the fact that the actual golf mechanics feel woefully underdeveloped. The game seems to favor a grip it and rip it mentality as any attempt I made to be clever with my shots ended in utter disaster with the exception of the instances in which the game decided to make some sort of idiotic club selection—teeing off on a par five with an 8-iron for instance. Speaking of club selection a clunky interface makes proper club selection tedious. Players must enter the scout camera mode to see where their ball may end up with a solid shot and if players wish to see where a different club might place the ball, the scout mode needs to be exited and a new club selection needs to be made. Spinning the ball or controlling draw or fade is slightly awkward with a shot modifier that needs to be dialed in before making a stroke. There is also very little feedback when trying to control the strength of your shots. Taking a few yards off of a stroke becomes an exercise in frustration since the difference between 70% and 100% power is a millimeter of travel on the analog stick and there are no meters or other visual indicators to allow players to get a feel for it. If there is another way to modify the strength of your shots I could not find it and a tutorial was not provided. The game's bare bones approach also means that you are stuck with a fixed club selection so don't expect to carry a hybrid or a long iron in place of your five wood.  Thankfully, the course editor in The Golf Club does not disappoint. Offering desert, links, alpine, rural and autum tile sets and a wide array of props, the course editor easily allows players to build realistic courses with few limitations. A number of sliders that populate the world with vegetation, water and hills automates some of the more tedious aspects of design. Bridges, wildlife, structures and props allow you to breathe life into each hole and imbue your course with some personality. Editing can be done hole by hole or freely across the entire course. Coupled with the game's mostly pleasing visuals it's exciting to turn your vision into a virtual reality and then share it with the world. It's just a shame that the frame rate can be slower than the senior tour—even on powerful hardware. The Golf Club brings to mind all of those 1990's home designer software packages available in most electronics stores. Teeing off in The Golf Club is underwhelming but creating courses is any golf fan's dream. The actual golf is a bit clunky and in need of a swing coach with it's poor feedback, lack of club selection, and cumbersome UI. The lack of atmosphere and character progression do little to incentivize actually playing the game. While The Golf Club hasn't quite passed Q School, it's not entirely irredeemable. With so few choices for PC gamers, The Golf Club is worth considering for serious golf fans, those on consoles have a little more to consider but the course creator is quite compelling. In the end, The Golf Club logs a bogey on the score card.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I originally gave this game a thumbs up, but after so many hours of frustrations and things that don't or half work I am done with it. I almost punched my monitor the last time I played out of frustration. In the 90 hours I have played I think I have uninstalled this game at least 6 times due to rage quitting, only to reinstall it again the next day and giving it an other go. So the game was already frustrating from day 1, but the game also has a lot going for itself so I kept comming back for more. Enough is enough now, the frustrations while playing the game are not healthy for me. If the frustrations were the result of my own errors and bad playing it would not be a problem, but the game coding and design is to blame here. Issues:There are so many times that the game doesn't register your swing (with the mouse) properly and you end up hitting the ball with 70% power. You spend already 45 minutes on a course trying to hit the best you can and then the game just screws it up by not registring your swings while you hit just as hard as the other swings that got registered as 100% power. It also can happen that the ball mid air takes a sharp right/left turn while you swing straight. And no this is not due to ball effect or wind, it is the game that again not registers your swing correctly. It almost feels as a prescripted 'bad swing'.There is a course creator, which in itself is a great feature. The game laysout a random course for you with a course generator. After that you want to edit it, but you have to do that through an afwul User Interface with sub menu's. After 20 hours I was still searching for the right feature constantly. The editor also lets you NOT edit vital parts of the course, good luck adding fairway to raised land, it won't let you. A nice guy on the forum tried to help with explaining a way to bypass the flaws of the creator, but after almost 30 hours in the creator without having made even 1 decent course I gave up, it's not worth the hassle.Also things like Alt Tabbing out of the game and then opening the game again keeps the game in windowed mode. Pressing Alt Enter to go to full screen again opens an other instance of the game while not closing the windowed instance on the background... so you have now 2x the game running with 50% less FPS. Press Alt Enter more times and it keeps adding running instances of the game in the background.This game could be a great game and in between the frustrations I did had fun, but there are things wrong under the hood of the game that sucks the fun out of it and makes it unnecessarily a frustrating flawed game. The community seems pretty decent and helpful, it's not their fault.They are creating a TGC2, I sure hope it will not be as flawed as this version.The game has a lot of potential and it could definitely be my favorite golf game, but they really need to try to get all the nice features and ideas implemented with better coding under the hood and preferably with an other game engine that is more optimized at rendering 1000+ trees and water and stuff. Sadly after +90 hours and an initial thumbs up it has become a thumb down.Still, if you see this game on a nice sale, grab it. It will give you some hours of fun. Just stop playing when the frustrations start to kick in.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATED 17/06/2015I've been gaming since the '70s and I've played a lot of different games over that time on a lot of different systems.  But until now I've not known a games company support their product like HB have.  It is still receiving incredible updates; so much so that it is almost unrecognisable to the original release.The game has swallowed my life.  Buy it.ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOWI've spent a lot of time with this game now and I'm looking forward to spending more time with it.At the time of review, this game is in Early Release.  But you wouldn't know.  If you pay your money now then you are getting a highly polished game.  If you like golf, you'll love this.The game itself is immensely addictive.  It is much more of a simulation compared to the nonsensical arcade style of Tiger Woods (Hit a good shot, penalised because you weren't wearing a Nike wristwatch?).It is easy to hit a bad shot on this game and putting can be difficult.  But hit a good shot and you'll be rewarded - just like real golf.  And that is the point.  It *feels* like real golf.  You'll get frustrated at your bad shot 'cos you know you can do better.  You'll stop and think on each of your shots.  A good round of golf *feels* like a good round.  If you've played golf games in the past then you'll know how much of an achievement this is.  And I've been playing golf games since NIck Faldo Plays The Open came out on the Spectrum in 1985.The course creator is a real gem.  It is a beautiful tool.  Take a look at the game's forums and see some of the creations that have been put down by the community.  Many people have spent 50 hours + on their work - and it shows.  But the real beauty is the simplicity of the tool.  You can create a beautiful course in no time at all - and with little effort.  But if you put a bit of effort in, then you and others will appreciate the results.Proposed additions to the game will make this even better.  Frankly, this is a must buy for anyone with an interest in golf.  You won't be dissapointed.

												IMHO, there's a glitch with the game. As of this entry, that glitch has not been fixed. Not being able to complete my swing began after I upgraded to Windows 10. What I found worked in that situation where I couldn't complete my swing was, while still on the hole I was having problems completing my swing on I hit alt+enter, clicked inside the game window, then hit alt+enter again. This caused some artifacts to appear. Then I hit the escape key, clicked exit game, clicked accept, then, from the main menu I resumed the game, then I was able to complete my swing and continue play and didn't notice any more swing hang ups. Hope this helps.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2016
												I am a golf casual, I do not watch, play or follow the sport, but the games have always interested me. Coming from the era of Sensible Golf on the Amiga 1200, and the PGA Tour series on the Mega Drive, it has been a rather long time since playing a golf sim, unless if you count GTA V, of course.I tired Perfect Golf some weeks ago, before the rebranding, and I had to refund that in about half hour. It was clunky, terrible detailing, and poor selection of courses. I picked this up in the sale today, and it is just miles better. Visually and mechanically better, with hundreds of official and fan made courses availible at a few clicks, offers much more variety straight off the... club (not bat, obviously).The progression system here seems to make more sense, and I can see that online play would be super fun with like minded friends. And controller support, which suits me more for a game like this.There may be a slightly tongue in cheek humour to this sim for those that, shall we say, need to adapt to how to swing effectively, but you can always mute the snarky commentator. For a Unity title it is pretty smart, and looks nice enough on the default/lower settings (GTX 970), but would need a Titan or the new GTX 1080 to really push the detailing and keep it above 60fps.For a non-branded golf sim this is pretty sweet, and one of the better choices on Steam.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, I've been mostly trying to stay away from early access games, particularly story driven games, which, in my opinion, are very ill suited for early access.  However certain types of games are well suited for early access, and sports games fall into that category.  Plus, I was really desperate for a golf game, so I took a chance and picked up The Golf Club.This game has a ton of potential and is already in pretty decent shape, for something this far from being finished.  The game is very playable right now, even though many modes and features are missing, as is to be expected of an early access game.I really enjoy the mechanics of the game.  This is not your standard 3 click fare.  I have yet to play with the mouse, but gamepad controls work really well.  You aim with the left thumbstick and swing with the righ, pulling back to wind up, then pushing up to swing.  Hitting standard full power shots is relatively straight forward.  Intentionally hitting a slice or hook to get around an obstacle, or doing a 3/4 swing is much much touchier and riskier, as it should be.  There is also less hand holding than in most golf games, which is great.  You need to figure out effects of wind and such on your own.A highlight of the game is the course creation tool.  While it's missing some templates at the moment, as well as a lot of features, it;s already a really good and robust tool.  With a few parameters you enter the tool will procedurally generate a course in seconds, then you can tweak the course to your heart's content.  There are already hundreds of user made coursed published, some hastily slapped together or nonsensical, but many really beautiful and well made.In conclusion, this game is already pretty good, and it will only get better from here on out.  I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a golf game.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												I've been playing PC golf games since Mean 18 back in 1986. This is a game I'd give a "meh" to more than  just Yes or a No, but considering the lack of development the last few months I'm giving it the thumbs down. That's mostly due to the launch condition of the game. There are some sins that should not be tolerated by the public and the launch of this game was abysmal.The Golf Club is a pretty mediocre representation of golf with issues that have been around since it launched in early access - inconsistent swing meters, very poor performance, dull voice overs, varying object qualities, iffy physics, overpowered wind and a few other problems. Anyone who claims this is a "simulator" doesn't understand the meaning of the word. You can tweak your shot, but the shot mechancis themselves are uninteresting and (unfortunately for multiplayer) extremely easy to "cheat" with. Edging with the mouseswing is a common problem online and in virtually every match you'll run into someone who is using it to hit every shot dead straight. The career mode was released later and is DLC, which didn't make me too happy considering the massive release problems. Customers should have gotten more for their loyalty and patience.That doesn't mean that the game is totally horrid. If you're lucky enough that the game runs well for you, then you're less likely to run into the swing meter issues (they're often based on sudden frame rate drops). Get the right course at the right time of day and the game can be quite attractive. The course designer isn't as powerful as some, but it's quite easy to use and the pregeneration of terrain is something that is a great idea. It's a Power to the People course designer and you'll see lots of them, some of them quite clever.The devs are hit and miss. They are not bad folks, but they knew a lot of these problems existed and rushed the game out the door to match the console release (and it's quite obvious this is a console golf game first and foremost). So fixing obvious problems like the green grid not working or being able to retract your course from the public (if you accidentally published it) have gone lacking. The short game is another place in this that the game is abysmal - forget trying to hit half or three-quarter shots because the mechanics don't lend themselves to doing so. Some of these issues have been subsequently fixed. Some have not. The post-December patch seems to have improved performance. They've stoped farting  around with trying to boost the user ratings of their own courses. In short, they've made progress. This is the good part. However, it's still not a simulation and there's no way I'm giving this a thumbs up because of the horribly botched release and months of inaction of their part.However, the swing is still tempermental and relies on frame rate to achieve 100%. Turn the settings up and the swing meter goes wonky. And now there's too many really lousy courses to comb through, so finding something worth playing has become an exercise in futility. What's worse is that you can't even provide any kind of decent feedback and to rate the course you still have to complete the round. Who wants to complete a round on a course that sucks? That's both the good and the bad part of having a designer that will spit out somewhat ready-made courses. You simply get an overabundance of stuff to choose from but then finding a good course is like looking for a needle in a haystack.Personally, I find that Perfect Golf simply "plays" a much better round of golf. Then again I'm partial to that Links 2003 style of approach to golf. YMMV but I'm glad this isn't the only PC golf game on the market. Long story short, good effort, mediocre execution, questionable development...equals thumbs down (or at least buy only on sale). I can't recommend this at full price.

												Bought this in a sale a few weeks ago, and I've been enjoying both playing and creating courses. The gameplay is quite pared back, which I think works quite well. I play on a controller, and it's difficult to control distance except with 100% shots, which I think is quite realistic. Worth checking out a guide on the putting though. Easy once you know what you're doing, but control of distance while putting is not explained in the game itself.Only thing I don't like is the way bunkers are treated, where they just reduce the club distance by e.g. 50%, regardless of whether the ball is plugged or just trickled in.Best thing about the game is the huge number of user created courses, both recreations of real-world courses and original courses. Creating courses is straightforward after watching a youtube video or two, although the course creater seems to have been designed with a controller in mind rather than mouse and keyboard.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												The sim has potential, even though it was most likely released prematurely. The course editor is fair, although it too, seems to be lacking some. Having said that, it is possible to produce a nice course with effort.Downside is anyone and everyone can publish a course.  Some are great while mose are just Auto-generated with no real thought placed into them. Making a hugh library of crap courses.  Problem here is you don't know how bad they are until you play them. Even a few of the "HB Official" course are questionable.  A course review by users would help determine which course would be worth playing. but, then you have to weed out the "typical" bash or praise user comments.  Ditto on the course rating system.  ratings are worthless without some sort of commentary to back them up.However, this is no reason to at least purchase the sim and try it yourself. It is worth the 35 dollars.  It does appear that HB Studios is working on continual improvements for the PC user side of the coin.  I'm not a fan of "console" sim games.  Console and serious "Simulation Games" and non exsistant in my opinion.  I know this is harsh to some, but being old school hard core computer geek.  Consoles will never match to power of a high-end computer sim.  Software companies save cost issues on coding for multi-gaming platforms and Console gamers make them the most money, so the PC user usualy is the Dinosaur in the room for gamers.I still think that in the end, if you're a PC gamer, this wll be a great sim after a few more patches and issues get resolved.Getting it now will allow you to get use to the gameplay and feel for what HB has done.  Graphics are great eye-candy, but can be taxing on a even a high-end video card.I still find this sim very enjoyable. And at times, just as frustrating as in "real" golf!

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												As you can probably see, this game has mixed views and opinions on whether or not this game is worth it. Hopefully this review can help you decide whether the game is worth it or not.If you are interested in playing an unlimited amount of courses created by yourself and thousands online, if you like to build courses with an excellent course creator, if you want a game that is considered a "golf simulator", if you want a golf game with a fun, active forum community and if you want a golf game with a VERY ACTIVE dev team, this is your game. This game is truly just about the golf itself.If you are looking for a golf game with a crowd cheering behind you, to play on a tour (amongst the pros) and earn cash or XP to customize what your character is wearing and how he looks plus the gear he is using, to level up your golfer, to play with pro players, and to play on real courses, this is not the game for you. People have, HOWEVER, recreated a TON of real courses in The Golf Club, and many, many of them are FANTASTIC!In general: Don't waste your money on this if you aren't truly looking for a golf game that is focused primarily on the golf itself. If you are more interested in how your character looks and levels up, I'd look elsewhere. I, myself, LOVE this game, as I care much more about the golfing experience rather than character customization, a tour and a crowd. I followed this game months before its release date, and the game has done nothing but improve over its lifespan.These are just my opinions! Overall: 8.5/10; recommended for gamers (or golfers) wanting a golf sim.EDIT: I also forgot! It is recommended that you have a controller, such as a wired xbox 360 controller, to play this game.
